Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + By \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = Cx + Dy \\), where A, B, C, and D are constants. We study the effect of a linear transformation of variables defined by the matrix \\( T = \\begin{pmatrix} P & Q \\\\ R & S \\end{pmatrix} \\), applied initially at time t = 0.

Does applying the transformation \\( z'(0) = Tz(0) \\) and subsequently letting the system evolve according to \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + By \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = Cx + Dy \\) lead to the same state at time t = T as if the transformation was not applied?
Explanation: Applying the transformation matrix \\( T \\) alters the initial state \\( z(0) \\) which affects the overall trajectory of \\( z(t) \\). Given the differential governing equations, the evolution of \\( z(t) \\) will diverge from the trajectory of an untransformed initial state, affected by the matrix components P, Q, R, and S.

causal_map_integration: Applying the transformation T changes the initial state of the system, leading to a new state z'(0), which then influences the evolution of x(t) and y(t). The constants A, B, C, and D govern the dynamics of x(t) and y(t), which in turn determine the state of the complex function z(t).
